questions.question: What coordinates multiple devices?
questions.explanation: DMA: direct memory access for devices. Benefit: CPU freed from data transfer. Speed: faster than CPU-mediated. Channels: multiple simultaneous transfers. Conflicts: resource contention possible. Modern: integrated into devices. Importance: I/O performance critical.

questions.question: What provides electrical stability?
questions.explanation: VRM: stabilizes CPU voltage. Phases: multi-phase for precision. Quality: affects stability, overclocking headroom. Efficiency: reduces heat. Ripple: noise minimization. Design: motherboard critical component. Failure: system instability, crashes.

questions.question: What handles thermal management?
questions.explanation: Sensors: monitor temperatures. Throttling: reduce speed if overheating. Benefits: protection, longevity. Limitations: performance impact. Algorithms: balance thermal and performance. Importance: system reliability. Tuning: control behavior.

questions.question: What bridges memory and I/O?
questions.explanation: Memory controller: manages RAM access. Location: typically on CPU (modern). Timing: coordinates reads/writes. Performance: latency impacts. Refresh: DRAM maintenance. ECC: error correction (if supported). Speed: matches CPU/motherboard.

questions.question: What distributes power efficiently?
questions.explanation: PDN: power distribution from PSU. Quality: voltage stability affects performance. Capacitors: stabilize voltage spikes. Traces: PCB design critical. Efficiency: minimal losses. Tuning: possible in BIOS. Importance: stable power essential.

questions.question: What protects against surges?
questions.explanation: Surge protector: limits voltage spikes. Importance: hardware protection. MOV: metal oxide varistor absorbs surge. Response: nanoseconds. Failure: sacrifices itself. Replacement: necessary after surge. UPS: uninterruptible power supply alternative.

questions.question: What enables expandability?
questions.explanation: PCIe: PCI Express standard. Versions: PCIe 3.0, 4.0, 5.0 (increasing bandwidth). Lanes: determine speed. Hot-swap: remove/add without reboot. Backward compatible: older cards work. Power: dedicated pins on slot. Importance: future upgrades possible.

questions.question: What optimizes memory bandwidth?
questions.explanation: Interface: connects CPU to RAM. Bits: 64-bit, 128-bit, or more. Frequency: MHz or GHz. Bandwidth: bits per second. Latency: affects performance. Modern: very high speeds (DDR5 6000+ MHz). Importance: performance critical factor.

questions.question: What manages data transmission?
questions.explanation: SerDes: converts parallel to serial (or vice versa). Efficiency: reduces pins needed. Speed: high-frequency operation. Power: reduces compared to parallel. Examples: PCIe, USB, SATA. Implementation: protocol-specific. Importance: enables high-speed interfaces.

questions.question: What prevents electromagnetic interference?
questions.explanation: Shielding: Faraday cage around sensitive circuits. Purpose: prevent EMI/RFI interference. Grounding: critical for effectiveness. Design: PCB layout matters. Cables: shielded types available. Importance: signal integrity protection.
